reviewText:
Don't be quick to judge The Consuming Shadow by the cover graphics. Sure, they certainly lack in production value, but not in impact. Twitchy sihoulettes of enemies, roadsigns and houses covered in heavy fog, special effects of unholy spells and crawling insanity - they're all simple, but they create a suprisingly strong sense of immersion once you familiarize yourself with the gameplay.

That would be easy, because, unlike most games of this kind, there are not that many aspects and resources to manage. You only have health and sanity as your stats, ammo, medical supplies and drugs as resources, and some buffing items which you may find as you explore the shadow-infested Britain, helping civilians and completing simple tasks while trying to avert the invasion of a malevolent god.

This doesn't mean it's easy to reach any of the good endings. You will die a lot, sometimes by your own hand, i.e. hitting 'Kill yourself' button which plagues your interface at low sanity. The combat system of this game takes some mastery and experimentation, however simple it may seem on the first glance. Carefully observing monster patterns and utilizing this knowledge will keep your health and sanity at tolerable levels. The combat and overall playstyle are also dependent on the character you play, which there're four.

The game, while being text-reliant, manages to avoid being text-heavy. The necessary information, describing the immediately concerning events and encounters, is written in condensed and atmospheric sentences. And, if you want, there's a whole lot more to read in the diary and enemy files which you collect across your playthroughs.

The sound and music also contribute greatly to the overall atmosphere. Calm and depressing piano pieces combined with eerie ambient noises really hit the spot. There's a practical component too - you can determine which kind of enemy you encounter even without seeing it. This is very important in the game when you can't see most of the room you're in.

For 10 bucks, The Consuming Shadow is a good deal - there's enough content for about 15-20 hours of gameplay, and the game is balanced to be challenging, but not frustrating.

reviewText:
The Consuming Shadow is an excelent mix of horror with retro gameplay. Simple at a glance but surprisingly deep you'll find yourself zipping around a randomly generated British countryside slaying demons and helping wayward souls in your mission to discover the dark god invading the world and the ritual required to banish it.

I could most easily compare the basics of dark-god banishment as a sort of game of Clue, for those who remember the boardgame pasttime, a deductive reasoning experience where you strive to find clues infering what gods are present and what symbols they use with the goal of figuring out which god is invading and what rune holds its affinity. Combing the god's rune with a discovered ritual will allow you to make an attempt at saving the world in Stonehunge, if you can survive long enough to get there.

Combat is hectic and claustrophobic as you battle quick, silhouetted beasties with limited light, pistol-whipping and firing wild shots in oppressively poorly lit dungeons. Choosing the right tactic, ammo and timing are all important.

Magic plays a role as well as you must utilize a collection of runes to both banish dark gods as well as cast spells you may find in your searches, counterspell evil cultists to defeat their magical barriers or to close rifts allowing shadowy creatures into the living world.

Resource management, time management, trigger discipline, reasoning skills and a bit of a gambling nature all play their part in the game. Do you want a few extra hollow point bullets, or the useful piece of gear? Wlil you gamble on your intuition to keep you from wasting ammo on hallucinations as your sanity wanes, or shoot up with illicit narcotics to keep your calm? Should you try and stop the crazed gunman with your words or your hands?

New to the Steam edition are a number of challenge modes including a daily challenge with randomized modifiers, achievements and trading cards. There are several unlockable characters with differeing capabilities and a somewhat gentle progression system that optionally allows you to get a little bit better with each run if you so choose by spending 'birth stars' on a series of randomized stat boosts.

The Consuming Shadows won't be for everyone. Watch some videos and decide for yourself, what you see is what you get. It'll either be amazingly cool or completely out of your range of interests. And don't mind my playtime, I put quite a lot of time into it when it came out in the Humble Store. It will likely grow in time.

reviewText:
Fun fun fun.
Is the game worth playing? Yes
Is it worth 10 bucks? Ehhhhhhh... That'll be up to you, of course.

It's a very well written and designed game. Not scary, nor particularly distrubing, but it is very very creepy. The art direction, although very simple, is also perfectly fitting. Even the text assets are acceptable despite being default plaintext, seeing as the character is either typing it out or reading it on typed paper.

The gameplay is uniqe, as far as I know. You simply walk left and right through procedurally generated dungeons and events, shooting, bashing, looting, running, and incanting your way past your foes. You have both health and sanity to monitor, of course. What makes it fun is whodunit take on figuring out which evil entity to banish, piece by piece assembling the know how to save the world. The fittingly abiguious yet descriptive writting also helps. Yes I know that's oxymoronic, but it just works.

The challenge is tight. At first I was sceptical of the difficulty. Then I realized you drain your health kit like a bullet hole riddled tub drains water. Then I couldn't find a way to permenantly restore sanity. Then I had broken legs, a panic attack, an was gushing blood, and proceded to clear three more towns that way before dying. ♥♥♥♥ was tense.

Replayability also seems very high, which is good for a session based game like this. If you've played FTL, you'd probably find Consuming Shadow's game sessions similar in length. Besides the main gameplay supported story and unlocks, you also have a daily challenge generator, and an endless dungeon mode. The list of individual challenges you can also unlock is short, but the game makes up for it in other unlockables. It has a diary you can rebuild, page by page. It also has a typical 'bestiary', but one that unlocks word by word, creating a more rewarding 'bestiary' to fill than most every other game has.

In conclusion, sure, the game has problems. The obvious how did they miss that" graphical bug
date: the graphics that obviously auto-scale for bigger monitors
recommended: and keys can't be rebound in the options. These little problems pale in comparison to everything it does right. Overall
hoursPlayed: I'd ask you to overlook the rough edges and buy this game if it interested you in any way."

reviewText:
If you want flashy graphics and large action set pieces, this game is not for you. Before you start The Consuming
Shadow you need to accept that you aren't paying for the tighest and sharpest pixels but you are paying for : an intriguing world to explore;masterful writing;interesting and refreshing gameplay mechanics ; a tense and sometimes horrifying atmosphere and an all around hardcore rougelike experience.

This game is not for the faint of heart or easily frustrated. You will die over and over again, It's entirely possible to have 'lost' a playthrough in the first 5 minutes. However, every playthrough grants you a greater understanding of what you need to accomplish and how you are going to do it. The 'Birth Star' or levelling system allows you to customise a characters skills and abillities before a game even starts. Each character is different, with their own playstyles, endings, backstories, pros and cons.

You'll also find yourself in some very uncomfortable situation as you traverse England and Wales in the days leading up to the apocalypse. Do you attempt to save a child from a burning car, injuring yourself? Do you leave your car to join a congregation, only to find that they are minions of the very evil you are trying to banish?

My one nitpick is that the randomness of events,encounters and resource avaliabillity can often lead to certain tasks becoming nigh impossible to complete. It can lead to some frustration but overall it hardly detracts from the overall experience.

If you enjoy rougelikes, Lovecraftian horror and a rich atmosphere and world, you owe it to yourself to pick up this game.

reviewText:
I've already put quite a bit of time into the Humble Store version of this game and I have just recently claimed my Steam Key; so I am checking out all the new features, but I will bring you up to speed on what I already know about this game.

The Consuming Shadow is a roguelike RPG much in the vein of FTL, with the overall goal of the game being stopping a Cthulhu-esque entity (simply called 'the Ancient')  from invading our world. This is done in both of the primary 'game modes' The Consuming Shadow features. The first is the overworld map, where you pick a town on your GPS and drive there via your very slow car to look for clues. Various 'text-only' events can happen both here and in the towns, where you will have to make a choice. These choices like FTL, can give you bonuses to your cash or equipment, or screw you over royally. There are often pieces of equipment you can use to sway these events in your favor, much like FTL.

The meat of your clue-finding will be done in the dungeon crawling sections however, where you enter a 2D side-scrolling section to kill monsters, open locked doors and scavenge chests. It is worth noting that while the keyboard controls function okay here, I found a PS3 or 360 pad is vastly superior. The keyboard controls remind me something of playing Resident Evil on a PS1 emulator, where your hands are spread thin across the keyboard. Speaking of Resident Evil, monsters are plentiful and ammo/health is scarce. You will have to wisely manage your bullets and learn how to melee attack most of the enemies to do well; running from encounters is NOT advisable, as you will take a penalty to your sanity for doing so.

The goal of each dungeon is to find a clue that will help you stop the Ancient, and ultimately you will need two things to win the game: A four-part Banishment Spell and the rune of the invading Ancient. The Banishment Spell is quite easy to attain, but finding the rune of the invading Ancient is tricky. You will need to use logical inferance and vague clues to figure out who is invading, who isn't invading, who is the God of what and so on. This is the funnest part of the game for me, as it balances the action elements with a fair bit of brain-teasing. The Ancient who is invading and what his rune is random on each playthrough too, so don't bother trying to reuse anything for a new run.

There are also a total of four different characters to play as, and unlocking them depends on a good deal of RNG unfortunately, but it's a wonderful way to mix things up. There are also some ties into Yahtzee's other games (Trilby and Chzo) but I haven't touched those yet, so I can't tell you if they are significant.

Overall the Steam version is the same game (duh), it essentially just adds in some extra monsters and challenge modes if you find the main game to be getting stale. None of my complaints about the original game have been addressed; the visuals on some simple things (like your GPS) can be improved, and there should be more backgrounds for the 'text-only' events that happen on the road and in town.

None of this detracts from the gameplay though; if you enjoy Lovecraftian horror, light action and puzzle solving this game will keep you distracted for quite a while.

One of the finest, and truest to form Lovecraftian games available. The Consuming Shadow invites its players to come along on an adventure that's ripped right out of pages of the Providence writer's imagination. There are dozens of little details that fine tune the mood and atmosphere to just the right amount of uncertainty, danger, and dread, that the new player is never quite certain of what is going on while the veteran player is always unsure of what exactly is coming next. The game provides a sense of mystery in that the player must pursue information and collect clues in order to deduce just which god is invading, and which spell to cast in order to prevent this invasion. Through the powers of deduction and logical reasoning the player can find out exactly what they're up against, all while avoiding the terrible effects the invading god is having on the countryside around them.

Highest marks to its designer Yahtzee, and one of the best Lovecraftian horror games on the market.

I've been playing this game for much longer than 8 minutes, I played primarily on the version from the Humble Store. This steam key was also included if the game got greenlit, so I put in just a few minutes to share my thoughts.

When someone says that RNG can't make an experience that draws desperation and fear, be satisfying and not devolve into a frustrating pile of dogshit, this is the game that I will show them.

Yahtzee Croshaw is a well known critic of games and game design, and it seems he with this game, he shows that he can put his money where his mouth is.The game is incredibly well balanced, with every playable character having a different playstyle that will draw you into the world. Embark on an adventure, where ammo is scarce and every single item and clue is tantamount to preserving your life for that one last moment. The pool of dialogue and actions are somewhat scarce, but the ability to which they are done is profound. It's amazing that this game, with all of its well crafted design (bar the aesthetics that do the job but could be better), is  a simple logic puzzle at its core.

This game, despite its harshness, is fun. It's scary. It fills me with desperation knowing that it is up to me to help this man save the world before the toll on his mind breaks him, provided the monsters don't break his body first.

Everything has a lovecraftean vibe that only adds to the tension. I am filled with dread once I complete a mission, scared that a powerful monster will spawn in moments, where I begin to freak out and attempt to escape before the giant face that consumes the room will eat me as well.

The game makes the smart move of balancing everything, so that the penalties have a large effect on the game but do not simply cause them to kill you without warning. Every option has something that can help the situation and even then it still can dangle hope within your grasp, as you agonize over whether or not you should save a boy from a burning car.

This game has many random elements, but have been able to apply balance and design in a way that makes the things keeping RNG in check in a meaningful and useful way, without removing the emotions the game wishes to elicit in all of its scenarios. I feel bad when I lose, I am relieved when I win. I don't feel frustrated by the game's systems, because my actions are that; my actions. I am responsible for taking care of my character and it will be my choice that leads him to saving the world or shooting himself in the head.

Solid game. While some may dislike the art style, I think the silhouette-backlight design actually works in the game's favour, as it leaves more to the imagination and emphasizes the (very effective) sound direction as well. The various challenges and achievements finally add a lot of depth, although the character balance is... debatable. Most bugs have been fixed since the original release. The writing and atmosphere are amazing, especially if you consider it's a procedurally generated roguelike. You do get used to it after a while and you develop a tolerance to the creepiness, but the game can still surprise you occasionally - especially when you're trying for a really hard challenge.

There are some issues. The game could have used more character-dependent flavour texts. The text messages are personalized for each character, but the other situations (mostly) aren't. It can break immersion somewhat at certain points since their personalities are so different. My biggest complaint is that you have to pay birth stars (character levels) to unlock new challenges. This means that a level 10 character can only get 2 (I think) stars at the start with all challenges unlocked, which makes the game even more difficult - as if it weren't difficult enough - and you'd have to play a LOT to make up for those lost stars because the XP requirement for newer levels increases exponentially. I think that area could have used a little more tweaking.

Finally, I'm glad I got this on the day of the summer release for a cheaper price with Yahtzee's two novels thrown in, because the current price is really friggin' high for such a low-production (which is obviously not the same as bad")

Wow, great game, honestly. I haven't even unlocked the last character yet, and I'm not even close to ending the game properly with all the other characters. The game has a lot of content, you see. I've been a fan of Yahtzee's for a while now, enjoying his earlier works, as well as the various series he does on youtube these days, so it comes as little surprise to me that he hits it out of the ball park with this one. The randomly generated nature of the game makes it different every time, and I've only ever once ran into an error with two assets not going together well and forcing me to restart the game. The writing, and  the themes of Lovecraftian cosmic horror in this game is pulled off fantastically.
The overarching puzzle mechanic of the game in which you must deduce who the invading god is is a fun little brain teaser. Nothing too brutal if you know what you're doing, but it can take you a bit at first.
Don't get me wrong though, the game is brutal. Very much so. Each and every dungeon that must be explored to complete the game holds creatures spawned from the ancients. Rusted metal and deformed flesh is waiting inside to break your bones and.. make you go to a hospital. Speaking of that, the enconomy must be pretty damn good over there in the UK if you can get a set of body armor for a mere 20 pounds.

The dungeons are mostly exploration based anyway, and it's done well. The art style itself is, well, very reminscent of flash games, but the animation is enough to make up for it, I feel.

If you like FTL, or you like Lovecraftian horror, definitely definitely definitely pick this one up. You'll be getting your moneys worth that's for sure.

reviewText:
The game does have some very telling issues: the visuals are less than flattering, the dungeon environments are repetitive, and the sound design is very average. I can hear the gap in the ambient audio loop when you visit an inflicted town, and the rain cuts out when you walk inside a house; in short, the sound design is basic, and - for the most part - is unnatural sounding. There are many minor details, apparently overlooked in development, which can take one out of the experience.

Despite this, The Consuming Shadow is still largely a very immersive game. Very few games capture the heavy atmosphere of dread that is essential to survival horror, and this is something that the game does well. It is a genuinely tense and unnerving experience, with the pressure of time constantly weighing down on you as you evade enemies via the extremely clunky control scheme, exploring dungeons looking for clues so that you may potentially save the world. The puzzle system is very well designed, allowing you to hazard a guess at who the invader might be, in case you lack some information as the time runs out. It expects you to think for yourself from the information gathered, rather than simply gather clues and expect the answer to be handed to you once you've collected enough, which is rare and worth praising.

Perhaps the strongest aspect of the game is the writing, and how the game treats writing as integral to the experience. It does lean somewhat towards the telling rather than showing, but the writing is solid nonetheless. Every piece of dialogue, monologue, fluff text, or any descriptions of any kind add to the overall atmosphere, and are more than barebones exposition.

So I would recommend this game; for the price it's worth checking out. It is an imaginative, tightly designed and highly atmospheric horror game that happens to be somewhat rough around the edges.

reviewText:
The Consuming Shadow, developed by Ben Croshaw, is a side-scroller, dungeon crawling rough-like with a horror paint job. Now, if you’re an avid Steam user, you’d know how many dungeon crawler rough-likes there are on the market. They’re worth a dime a dozen at this point. So, I was more than pleased when I found this little gem. It's amazing how unique and promising this game is opposed to the other.

Plot: A strange and horrific shadow is washing over Great Britain in full force. Cities have been ravished by otherworldly beasts, people have been melded into twisted shells of their previous selves, and in just three days, the country will fall… then the world. All mighty gods known as The Ancients are behind this mayhem, but it’s the player’s job to find out who’s to blame and banish them. You will travel from city to city, all across the UK in search of clues, answers, and knowledge.

As I mentioned before, The Consuming shadow really is its own game, and I doubt you can mistake it for another. Gameplay is rather straight forward, but it works great. You’ve got a plethora of items to find and collect, multiple ammo types, spells to master and more. Dungeons are grid based, and each one has its own objective. This may vary from securing an occult text, finding a missing person, destroying monster nests etc. And let me tell you, this game can be tough, and you will die. Monsters deal vicious damage and conserving ammo is not as easy as you might think. Driving also plays a big role in The Consuming Shadow. Driving from location to location takes time, so it’s important to set a predetermined path as to save every precious hour. But there’s a good chance you’ll bump into random events along the way. You’re usually given two choices to make, and more often than not, my decisions resulted in negative outcomes, like the loss of some health or sanity. There isn’t any pattern behind these events and making the right choice is based purely on luck.

There’s also a sanity meter that must be kept healthy. The madder you become, the more difficult the game is. But, unlike most games in the genera, dying isn’t a total lost. XP is still earned and built up through multiple playthroughs, and each time a player levels up, they’re given an array of buffs before they start their next run.

Now, this is where a complaint of mine comes in. The max level is ten, and if you were to spend all ten of your buffs on health and sanity increases, it makes the game a bit underwhelming. If I’m sporting 456 health, it’s gonna take A LOT to kill me. It also makes your first bunch of playthroughs damn-near impossible, seeing as how you start off with such low stats.

But apart from that… there really isn’t much to complain about, here. The Consuming Shadows accomplishes what it aims to do with flying stars, and apart from a couple gripes, I’d say it’s definitely worth your money.

reviewText:
I like Ben Croshaw and his body of work about as much as any reasonable person can. I don't always agree with his reviews or his style, but he has cheeky charm and a sense of old-school fun that I've come to enjoy. Mogworld was lovely and rather clever. Zero Punctuation is hilarious and often insightful. This game, however, is disappointing.

TL;DR: There are better roguelikes and better Lovecraftian games for around the same price point. I would struggle to recommend this game even if it were on sale.

The Consuming Shadow succeeds in two areas: difficulty and a cursory sense of novelistic credibility. I admit, Croshaw definitely pays proper dues to Howard Phillips Lovecraft. I admire his attempt at crafting a literary" roguelike. Yahtzee definitely TRIED to capture the atmosphere of cosmic horror

As of ~2 hours playtime, I have seen repetition of at least 3 of these random encounters (the hysterical woman on the side of the road, the businessman with a locked car, and the rescue of a person captured by cultists-- hilariously enough, the first time I shot the captive by accident, but the second time I was ready! Thanks, lazy programming!).\n\nLiterary though it may be, it fails to be genuinely interesting. Yes, Ben, you wrote some punchy sentences that, when jammed together according to certain scripts, make discernable paragraphs. None of these Mad Libs: Eldritch Edition" entries are special nor particularly good. After trying very hard to enjoy the writing for some time

and the fellow was selling hollowpoint ammunition and SKATEBOARD PADS. I know I'm not supposed to take it entirely seriously, but narrative consistency from a published author shouldn't be a tall order.

The game succeeds in being difficult, although not often for the right reasons. Because of the two-dimensional viewpoint, some overlapping enemies will be completely obscured at the outset of combat. Sanity loss is expressed in hallucinations and control manipulation (left is right and right is left, sometimes your character disappears, etc.) This is fun in an old-school way but is poorly executed and unbalanced. Lost ~20% of your sanity? You may end up accidentally killing yourself when the game starts flashing a suicide option over your medkit button. No, I'm not complaining that this happens, I'm frustrated that this happens with so much sanity remaining. It doesn't make sense. Hit detection is poor, and it is impossible to manually aim. On several occasions, I was staring down two or three foes and found myself unable to aim at the most dangerous, difficult-to-avoid enemy. A simple targeting option? Strangely absent.

The Consuming Shadow clearly capitalizes on the replay value associated with roguelikes, but unfortunately it doesn't provide enough variety to make it worthwhile. What are you to expect from adding handicaps from the various challenges offered? More of the same. Even as I progressed, gaining more customization options with birthsigns, for instance, (options which give the player various stat bonuses) I never felt as if I were enjoying the game more nor that the options available genuinely added to my experience. It felt lazy, just as many roguelikes feel lazy. It seems that with many indie devs, if you can't write a good story or design a good level, you make a roguelike.

Additonal notes:

-Achievements are basically broken: I have received achievements for collecting all diary pages (which I haven't), rescuing 20 unbrainwashed humans (haven't done that either) and completing 50 dungeons (definitely have not done that).

-Even if you can hear and partially see an enemy, if you fire from too great a distance, your shot will be wasted. It is still unclear to me why a targeting system is unavailable.

-All of the encounters are either a) fetch quests b) rescue quests or c) kill quests. All of the rooms in the game are roughly the same size, and all of the locations have the same meager handful of elements to work from. Outdoor environments have leafy walls instead of plaster ones, for instance.

I cannot recommend this game despite wanting to love it. I have played many roguelikes, and this is by far the most disappointing.

Edit: I am extremely grateful to Steam for granting my refund in spite of my 2.1 hours of playtime, the latter 20 minutes or so which I accrued by preparing for this review.

reviewText:
I bought this game on HumbleBundle two months ago and like what many have stated already, it combines the best of Arkham Horror and FTL which is the Lovecraftian atmosphere and the travel/roguelike elements. You are a single person trying to stop an Eldritch god from invading the world and taking over it and to stop it, you need to figure out the banishment ritual and which god is trying to enter. This game emphasizes time and resource management and how you approach situations. Rushing recklessly into a situation could cost your health, but the potential gains could be worthwhile.

Pros:

1. Great atmosphere, music and sound effects.
2. Using sillouettes rather than actual pictures for sprites makes you imagine what the horrors look like, which makes it much more tense.
3. Driving from town to town builds on feelings of isolation and urgency, adding to the theme of the game.
4. It is incredibly replayable, even with different characters.

Cons:
1. The animation is incredibly stiff. I know I shouldn't dock it points but Yahtzee said two sprites make up the characer; the body and the legs, and it shows.
2. The game is incredibly unforgiving, though this is a small complaint since you are going up against a supernatural force. The odds are indeed stacked against you.
3. Notes and dialog tend to repeat after ten plays or so, even if it is wonderfully written.

In all honesty, buy this game and play it. It's worth the money.

reviewText:
Spawned from the corners of a twisted, sarcastic and incredibly british man, The Consuming Shadow is best described as a detective-horror game with Cthulhian (Cthulian?) inspired mythos. Bit difficult to fully describe, to be honest, as there's a clash of game types going on here, but we have two major gameplay elements going through. Well, three technically, but there's some intermingling.

Firstly, you begin the game as one of the four playable characters (the other three being unlocked over the course of playtime and challenges) with the goal of stopping a nebulous, eldritch god from invading the world and unleashing unspeakable horrors upon the people. To do this, you have your car and notebook; the first used (rather obviously) to drive around the English countryside, hitting town after town, with the intent of gathering information. Any information you find is added to your notebook, for you to peruse at your pleasure and have your own little wall of crazy to find out who the invading god is so you can adequately fight them.

The usual way you find clues and information is through the second game mode, which are a Dungeon-like environment. In these Dungeons, you'll fight against enemies spawned by the invading god, monsters and twisted horrors normally, though average folk make their appearances. The combat mechanics are extremely simple: A gun for ranged combat with three ammo types (Standard 9mm, Hollowpoint, Armour Piercing), the ability to pistol whip, and the ability to cast spells for various effects.

Stats in the game are also extremely simple: you get Health and Sanity, both obvious in and of themselves, although Sanity is a subtle nuisance that slowly grows bothersome throughout the game. Health is reduced by taking damage, while Sanity is reduced slightly by being damaged by monsters, by encountering terrifying or disturbing events, or by casting spells of the shadow. Effects of low sanity range from illusory monsters to dungeon doors and areas shifting, quite varied. The most dangerous mechanic, however, is in the overworld, where when you have an event or choice to make (such as in towns or when someone flags down your car), the choices may occasionally start shaking and change to Kill Myself". Yes there's a suicide minigame

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by simple appearances, we don't judge by the cover here. While the only time I was a little scared playing this game was when it was pitch black and I had only this dark game to illuminate the room, I would recommend this well-crafted horror game.

Playing The Consuming Shadow is no cakewalk; you will die, and you will die a lot. Dying is an integril part of it, actually, as the longer you last in a game, the more EXP you earn when you die, and the more advantages you can gain the next time you play. It's nice to know a game isn't babying me for once. This is a game for real men. Or women. Or everything else.

It's very much centered around time/resource management, and actually requires you to pay attention and apply the clues you find to figure out the mystery, rather than just letting you complete your goal after a certain point has been reached. Even when I thought I was certain as to the identity of my adversary, I was completely bamboozled when I found more clues as I approached my destination; you can never be too sure, and one slip up will cost you the world.

Another thing worth mentioning is the sanity meter. You know how in games such as Amnesia: The Dark Descent, being insane just makes the screen wobble, and give your character a headache that sounds like you're walking on bags of crisps? Well, insanity is actually a hindrance in this game; you cannot cast most spells while insane, as casting spells costs you sanity, it will be harder to see, doors will switch positions, and sometimes you'll just feel the overwhelming desire to put the cold barrel of the gun to your head.

Overall, I definitely recommend giving this game a go. The game is hard, but not to an annoying degree; if it was, I probably wouldn't play it as much as I do. It will challenge you at every opportunity, be it with stronger monsters or fighting off suicidal instinct, and that's always a plus; no one likes a game that holds your hand to walk you across the busy freeway, they're letting you walk across yourself to most likely get hit by a speeding car or pull the trigger before the cars can do it for you.

Oh, and if the game by itself is too easy for you, there's always Scourge of the Ancients. Have fun trying to do that, achievement hunters.

...But uh, you can't actually consume the shadows, so. 0/10

reviewText:
The Consuming Shadow is an interesting, and I think mostly successful, take on the roguelike, sidescroller and adventure genres.

The random nature of the mystery gives it replayability, as you can never know which elder god you're facing without knowing most of the clues and taking educated guesses. The exploration and sidescrolling parts of the game are very simple, though, and I can see it becoming monotonous since you're always facing the same enemies with the same abilities in environments with very little to distinguish between them. Some variety would improve the game, as every room looks pretty much the same as every other room and every highway looks the same as another highway. The sanity mechanic is done well; the encroaching static and the disturbing flashes of things you see when you're driving with low sanity add to the oppressive mood.

I wouldn't say it's a scary game like Silent Hill or Fatal Frame, but there are surprises aplenty and the backstory is well-written and suitably Lovecraftian. I bought the game on sale and I'd say it was worth the time I've spent on it already

reviewText:
While I'm not a fan of the auto-aim system, where you're trying to hit the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ghost trying to kill you and instead you swat a fly, I'm really in love with this game.
Graphics are 'mediocre', but very atmospheric.
Writing's amazing.
Music's beautiful, even if it starts to get a bit samey over time.
The game's easy when you know what you're doing (banishing the big bad with over 20 hours to spare isn't hard if the RNG isn't actively hating you), but Challenge Mode will make sure you NEVER know what you're doing, which is perfect for players wanting a challenge.
The research 'minigame' is at times brainracking, and always very fun. That moment between casting the banishment ritual using the clues you'd gathered and the boss fight (or the lack thereof) is always incredibly tense, and it's euphoric being proven right (though this lessens with each playthrough). Sadly, none of the challenges do anything to try to make this aspect of the game harder - I'd love a mode where I had to decipher who the baddie was with the knowledge that there were FOUR gods in this fustercluck.
The game REALLY comes alive when you're close to losing (though this is true of everything, I think). When you're low on health and running away from a hunter, when you've got two minutes on the clock, are in stonehenge and have only half a banishment ritual, etc.
One extremely minor quibble I have (disregarding the first one) is that you can't just skip the astrology section once you've got birth stars. You HAVE to look for an empty space and choose it if you don't want any bonuses ruining your playthrough.
If I might suggest extra features, perhaps a hard mode where each astrology bonus comes with a penalty as well, or something - like, if you want +25 health, you have to take -25 sanity, or raising your medkit capacity means lowering your ammo-count, or something randomized.

If you want the game insultingly easy, and you've got some birth stars to spare, GET EXTRA AMMUNITION. Health and sanity are all well and good, but if you've got a tonne of ammo, you won't need to take hits to health or sanity at all. Once you maximize ammo capacity, you really only have to worry about your route and the clues - the game's extremely liberal with handing out ammo.
Alternatively, increase Melee and keep ammo for bosses. (Almost) Every single minor enemy can easily be beaten through pistol-whipping, so just keep doing that and learn each enemy's pattern.

reviewText:
I was very surprised by The Consuming Shadow.
The idea of a Lovecraftian Rogue-like dealing with the concept of cosmic horror is certainly an interesting one, and who better to make it than Yahtzee Croshaw, the maker of the brilliant video game review series Zero Punctuation.
What I Like:
- The concept is definitely worth praising right off the bat, especially when you see how this relates to the gameplay. You need to solve a mystery using a variety of clues that you need to desperately scavange from monster infested dungeons. You have a certain amount of time to solve said mystery, and if you get it wrong, it's all over.
You'll need to use your brain for this one. What do the clues mean? Do I have enough clues? Will I have enough time to get more? There's no one way to find the solution to the problem you're presented with, as everything is procedurally generated each time you play. And remember, if you don't get them all, you can always guess.
- The replay value of The Consuming Shadow is one of it's biggest selling points, I've only played for a few hours, but I can't help but return to it to try and achieve all the different endings, or even to have a crack at the daily challenge.
- The tone of a game like this is important, and in my opinion, The Consuming Shadow nails it perfectly. It's not the kind of horror that jumps out at you, but rather the kind of horror that may or may not be lurking around every corner. And... Well... You're never gonna be sure if there truly is something stalking you until it's burying it's teeth in your stupid face. The constant stress of a incomprehensible dark mass chasing you is thrilling, and at times really rather terrifying, which leads me onto my next point.
- It's actually scary at times. The music provided is nothing crazy or over-the-top, but it helps to add to the constant feeling of misery and the eventual demise of the entire universe, unless you do something to stop it. Plus, the big ticking clock very blatently in your field of view the entire time adds so much to the experience. You need to manage your time appropriately, and if you don't, don't expect to get very far.
- The last point I want to bring up concerns the lore of the game, and overall story. I'm not too sure I get it yet, and even if I did I wouldn't spoil it for anyone reading this, as it's meant to be worked out and interpretted in your own way. It's certainly mysterious, that's all I'll day.

reviewText:
60 hours to save the world. Can you banish the Ancient before the looming Shadow consumes us all?
The Consuming Shadow is a Lovecraftian Horror, hybrid adventure/action/detective roguelike game. Don't expect to get the best ending on your first run. Or your fifth. Or twentieth. The truly random nature of dungeons, shop equipment and random events makes every single playthrough different and challenging. I've been playing since the Humble release, and I just recently got the best ending.

Your main goal sounds deceptively simple - collect clues to find out which God is invading and what rune they’re associated with, deduce the four runes of the Banishment Ritual, then finally travel to Stonehenge and banish the hostile invading God. As you travel through the UK, you will be tasked with liberating fallen towns and keeping others safe from the influence of the Shadow. Hostages need rescuing, but sometimes it's too late. And make sure to keep an eye on the clock - the God is punctual and if you haven’t reached Stonehenge and banished it in time, you lose.

Finding out which God is invading and which of the five Runes they are associated with is not always easy, and neither is assembling the banishment ritual. Clues about each of the three gods, their color, aspect, rune and relationship to the other gods are hidden in dungeons, and the banishment ritual runes are often given as rewards for completing them. Sometimes you may find a lot of clues early on, and others you may find yourself with only a few hours left when you finally uncover the secret. Don’t let a lack of clues discourage you, though - if you think you have a good idea of the God’s rune and the banishment ritual and time is short, you can hoof it to Stonehenge and go in on your best guess.

Try to keep your health and sanity intact while you explore a variety of dungeons, slaying monsters with guns, melee attacks and (at the cost of some sanity) some helpful magic. Locked doors can interfere with your progress, and you’re not always lucky enough to find the keys, so keep your lockpicks handy. As your sanity drops, you’ll be plagued by a variety of problems, from illusory enemies to accidentally clicking the “Kill Yourself” option while trying to find supplies in town. Sometimes you’ll break an arm or a leg. You may become so anxious that firing your gun accurately becomes nearly impossible. Grotesque monsters like the Buzzer, a giant wasp-like creature; the Puker, a twisted humanoid that clings to the ceiling and vomits acid at you; and the Birther, a writhing mass that attacks by giving birth at you (no, really) will try to keep you from your goal. Unkillable hunters like the Overseer and the Tall Man will sometimes chase you from dungeons once you've reached your goal. These threats and more, plus the ever-looming 60 hour countdown clock, create a choking atmosphere of anxiety and horror.

The magic system is unique. Instead of having spells to start with and a traditional mana bar, you can find spells such as Clairvoyance (reveal the entire dungeon map), Healing Touch (regain HP), or Mass Death (deal heavy damage to everything in the room) as random drops in dungeons. Casting the spells requires the incantation of the correct runes, and every time you cast a spell, you lose some sanity. You can cast runes at random hoping to discover a spell, but casting the wrong runes can deal a pretty heavy blow to your sanity.

Alongside ammo and spells, you’ll encounter a variety of useful items as you progress through the game. Body Armor makes you take less damage, the Rosary helps keep your sanity intact, the Lucky Charm skews the odds in your favor a bit when it comes to finding items and ammo. Plenty of other items have helpful effects such as staving off certain status effects, and random events will sometimes go better if you have certain items with you.

Driving between the towns, there’s a chance that you’ll encounter random events, such as a husband attacking his wife, passing a nearby Church and wondering if you should drop in, or even getting pulled over by the police. Even using your best judgement, sometimes these things go wrong, and you can be pretty heavily penalized. I’ve had runs wherein I basically ignored all random events because I was having good luck and didn’t want to take too many risks.

An innovative level-up system allows you to customize your bonuses each time you play. Each level you gain grants you a Birth Star, which you can place in the sky to get bonuses to Sanity, Health, Ammo Capacity, Lockpicking Chance, etc. Some of the available bonuses are random, but I believe that Health and Sanity are always an options (which is good, because you’re going to need both of them. A lot.) Will you boost your health and focus on melee combat, or boost your sanity and cripple your opponents with magic? However you play, you’ll be dealing with random encounters, managing limited resources and hoping against hope that you can get the clues with enough time left to survive Stonehenge, banish the invading god and save us all.

I definitely recommend this game to fans of Horror, Adventure games and Roguelikes. Although the graphics are a bit basic, the overall atmosphere is fantastic and with three unlockable characters, the replayability is nearly infinite. Challenge modes, daily challenges, and The Descent (an infinite dungeon) have been added to the game for the Steam release, as well as nearly 100 achievements (and trading cards are on the way). There’s so much more to it that I haven’t even touched on in this review, but I want to let you discover that for yourself.

Good luck, Scholars. The clock is ticking...

I love this game. Originally bought it when it was released on HumbleBundle, hence my little playtime on the steam version, and loved it from the beginning.

Yes, it's a little clunky and the UI could do with some refining but the game itself is great. Solid design and the investigative gameplay is really fun. It's brutal and you both have to rush, due to the restrictive time limit, and take your time as to not take heavy damage to either your health or sanity.

I would recommend this game to anyone. If you can overlook the UI you gain access to a bloody brilliant game.
